Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
The Everest Advantage
By ELIZABETH A. HARRIS
1830 words
21 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
1
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

CLOSE your eyes and picture your dream apartment. Do you see light streaming through big open windows? Is there a large kitchen? Nice prewar detail?

Now open your eyes and remember that you are in New York City -- an extraordinarily expensive place to live, recession or no recession. So, what would you sacrifice to get a great place?

For many people, the answer can be summed up in one little word: elevator. If you are willing and able to climb the stairs to the fourth or fifth floor of one of New York City's 147,500 walk-ups, you may be rewarded with a little something extra at the top, like a better price, some private outdoor space or a great view.

''I grew up in Europe where there are lots of old buildings, so the stairs are natural,'' said Stephan Wessels, who lives on the fifth floor of a walk-up building with his wife, Elinor, and baby daughter, Juliana. ''I like the light, I like the fact that it's open, I like that nobody is on top of me making noise.''

Nonetheless, Mr. and Mrs. Wessels are trying to sell their Upper East Side apartment. Not to shed those four flights of stairs, he says, but because they want a second bedroom. Their child's crib is now in the hall.

''Fresh Direct delivers all the way up,'' Mr. Wessels said. ''That's a good thing to bear in mind.''

Their apartment, No. 5W at 334 East 83rd Street, has 700 square feet, with good light and a decorative fireplace. It's listed at $400,000, a lower price than comparable apartments nearby that do not require a climb. Last week, a similarly sized one-bedroom in an elevator building a few blocks away had an asking price of $445,000.

''Normally in a building that's not a walk-up, the higher you go, the more expensive it is,'' said Philip Horigan, the Corcoran broker with the listing on the Wessels property. ''But in a walk-up, the more you walk up, the cheaper it is. But you still get more light and more square footage.''

In addition to shaving money off the purchase price, a daunting set of stairs might also save an owner money on the monthly maintenance.

''It's a smaller segment of the market that's willing to walk four flights or more,'' said Jonathan J. Miller, the president of the appraisal firm Miller Samuel and a partner in Condominium Recovery, which invests in real estate. ''Most of these buildings are co-ops, and the share allocations are smaller as you go up because the value diminishes.''

In a soft market like this one, buyers are often unwilling to make sacrifices. So a drawback -- a location in neighborhoods politely referred to as ''emerging,'' say, or the lack of an elevator -- can be an even bigger-than-usual drag on the price.

''We couldn't believe what we got for the money,'' said Wendy Lichtenberg, a broker at Prudential Douglas Elliman whose stepdaughter just bought a large one-bedroom in a fifth-floor walk-up on the Upper East Side for under $600,000. ''Up 56 stairs to the Enchanted Egg,'' as we call it.

''It's her stairway to heaven,'' Ms. Lichtenberg added. ''Though honestly, at my age, would I want to walk up all those stairs? No, I would not.''

For young buyers, hoofing it may be the best way to get a top-notch apartment.

When Dani Super was apartment-hunting in her mid-20s, she needed a second opinion. Ms. Super took her mother, a former real estate broker, to a three-bedroom on the fifth floor of a late 19th-century walk-up building in Chelsea -- a place with the bones and architectural details to suggest that a woman in a hoop skirt might swish down the hallway at any moment.

''She walked in and screamed, 'We'll take it!' '' Ms. Super said, demonstrating how her mother marched through the apartment, charged with absolute certainty. ''This is it,'' her mother pronounced. ''You want something like this? You'll walk.''

She walked. But now, a decade later, that apartment, at 140 West 16th Street, is on the market again.

Ms. Super and her husband, Mike Davis, renovated the apartment two years ago with every intention of staying put. They updated the bathroom and the kitchen and built new closets in the master bedroom -- Ms. Super points out that the closets blend nicely with the Old World style of the apartment, but are outfitted to handle today's shoes.

But Ms. Super has a bad hip, and she and her doctors have decided that in the long run, it would be best if she skipped the stairs. So she and her husband are asking $1.295 million for their 1,600-square-foot apartment in the district of the well-regarded Public School 41.

''We'll probably look for exactly the same thing,'' Ms. Super said, ''just in Brooklyn and on the first floor.''

One feature that many top-floor walk-ups share is private outdoor space -- and some buyers think hauling laundry up a few flights is not so bad if you're just a few steps away from a nice quiet place to get a tan.

Jerry Minsky, a broker at Prudential Douglas Elliman, is selling a two-bedroom on the fifth floor of 328 Clinton Avenue in Brooklyn for $672,000. The price is no steal for a two-bedroom in that neighborhood -- Clinton Hill -- but at the top of those stairs is a private roof deck with panoramic views of brownstone Brooklyn and the Manhattan skyline.

''This is probably the way I should sell it,'' Mr. Minsky said, leaning back in a chair and pointing his face toward the sky. ''I should just sit up here with a buyer for an hour.''

But that may not cut it. Walk-ups can be a tricky sell, because it takes a delicate blend of circumstances to create a happy walk-up resident.

For a buyer of a certain age, all those stairs throw a wet blanket over the thrill of saving thousands of dollars. Having an elderly canine member of the family can make the journeys up and down tiresome, time consuming and kind of sad. And even people in the prime of life with the stamina to launch themselves from the first floor to the fifth without trouble -- hey, it's aerobic exercise, right? -- may find the climb unbearable if they are hauling along toddlers and strollers, too.

When Steve Linares moved to New York last year with his wife and two small children, he rented an apartment on the fourth floor of a walk-up in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. At the time he didn't even think about the stairs.

''I figured it was just one of the things that happened when you got to New York,'' he said. ''We moved here from California, I parked the truck outside and started moving things up stairs. I hated it that day.''

The apartment did not grow on him.

''It would be different if I was by myself,'' Mr. Linares said. ''But a 3-year-old wants to be carried on the way up and on the way down. You have the stroller. You have two backpacks. You frequently have to make two different trips.''

Mr. Linares, who is now separated, moved out this month. He has stairs inside his new rental, but his apartment door is on the ground floor.

So, would he buy in a walk-up?

''No,'' he said. ''Definitely not.''

Banks, too, can be squeamish about stairs. Some will not finance above the fifth floor of a walk-up building. Others will not go above the fourth.

''A lot of banks just won't do it because of marketability,'' said Julie Teitel, a mortgage broker at GuardHill Capital. ''I have a friend who has had a walk-up on the market for a year and a half, and they've lowered the price a lot. I'm tempted to buy it myself, but then no older people will come over.''

Veronica Coppey made a fourth-floor walk-up in Riverdale work for herfor over 45 years -- all the way through her 70s, and through three children. Now 81, she moved to an elevator building in the fall.

''I've always loved it,'' Ms. Coppey said. ''But it became more of a big deal as the years went on. My lady friends found it harder and harder to visit.''

The apartment has nice prewar detail -- including a dumbwaiter. But since many buyers in New York agree with Ms. Coppey's lady friends, Daniel Wright, a vice president at Halstead, has priced it accordingly. The asking price for her two-bedroom -- at 525 West 238th Street, a prewar building with Tudor flourishes -- is $275,000.

The Halstead Web site describes it plainly as the top floor of a walk-up. But some brokers are so concerned that the stairs will spook potential buyers that they don't mention this particular feature in the advertisement. They prefer to get the prospective buyer on the phone first, then slip in a mention of the stairs somewhere between descriptions of the light and the view.

Julie Rhinehart, a broker with Brown Harris Stevens, believes in being upfront.

Ms. Rhinehart is selling a small renovated three-bedroom at 397 Seventh Street in Park Slope for $859,000. In exchange for climbing to the fourth floor, you get a 250-square-foot roof deck with views of Manhattan, the Statue of Liberty and the harbor. The online ad is frank about the top floor.

''I put it right on the Web site,'' Ms. Rhinehart said, ''because the best way to market a property is to sell it for what it is.

''This is what the housing stock is made of. When you get to New York City, walks-up are a way of life.''

PHOTOS: ARE WE THERE YET?: For those willing to climb, walk-ups often cost less, or have a special feature, like abundant light or no one overhead. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY RUBY WASHINGTON/THE NEW YORK TIMES) (RE1); HUFF: A fifth-floor two-bedroom at 328 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, has a private roof deck; $672,000. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY RUBY WASHINGTON/THE NEW YORK TIMES); PUFF: A fifth-floor walkup on West 16th Street has an eat-in kitchen and three bedrooms; $1.295 million. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MARILYNN K. YEE/THE NEW YORK TIMES); GASP: A fourth-floor three-bedroom with a roof deck at 397 Seventh Street in Park Slope; $859,000. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY RUBY WASHINGTON/THE NEW YORK TIMES); WATER, PLEASE: A fifth-floor walk-up with one bedroom at 334 East 83rd Street; $400,000. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY MARILYNN K. YEE/THE NEW YORK TIMES) (RE9)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100321e63l0008v


IN THE REGION LONG ISLAND
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
Legislating Fairness in Co-ops
By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER
1001 words
21 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
8
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

CO-OP boards have long had the power to reject an application without explanation, leaving buyers and sellers to wonder whether discrimination was a motivating factor.

Barbara Ford, a lawyer and Realtor in Floral Park and the chairwoman of the Common Interest Ownership Committee of the Long Island Board of Realtors, found that troublesome.

''Because they never had to give a reason why the person was rejected,'' she said, ''it became a license to break the law.''

There are more than 9,300 co-op units in Suffolk County, with sizable developments in Coram, Patchogue, Bay Shore and Islip. Last year 294 units were sold, with an average price of $156,766.

Ms. Ford, determined to get the State Legislature to pass an antidiscrimination bill aimed at co-ops, made several attempts over the course of 15 years. But despite her group's lobbying, ''we were told that our efforts weren't going anywhere,'' Ms. Ford said, because organizations that own co-ops held more sway. Even when the House passed a bill, it would go on to fail in the Senate.

Last year, Ms. Ford decided she might have better luck with the county than the state. Along with her colleagues at the Realtors' board -- Randy L. Kaplan, the director of government affairs, and Kathy Engel, the president -- she approached the Suffolk County Legislature.

Steve Levy, the county executive, ''immediately embraced'' co-op antidiscrimination legislation, and within four months it passed.

The law took effect at the end of last year -- and it now appears likely to be introduced this year to the Legislature in Nassau County, which has concentrations of co-op communities in Great Neck, Mineola, the Five Towns and Long Beach. Last year in Nassau, 643 units sold, with an average price of $230,709.

The ordinance requires ''fairness in cooperative homeownership.'' Co-op boards must now state in writing why they have denied an application.

Mr. Levy described the new legislation as dovetailing with a 2007 housing bill that empowered local human rights divisions to investigate complaints.

Real estate transactions are generally protected by antidiscrimination rules, Mr. Kaplan said. But because co-ops sell corporation shares rather than actual real estate, they fall through a ''loophole in the law to allow discrimination.''

But the law has not been unanimously embraced. Thomas Flood, general manager and vice president of Richland Management, oversees 20 co-op buildings in Great Neck and 215 units in Hempstead. He described it as ''too complicated'' to have to give every potential buyer a reason for rejection. ''The law fails to recognize that when you have a co-op you have five to seven people making a decision,'' Mr. Flood said. ''It's the totality of the application and there are a lot of different factors.''

On the other hand Mr. Levy, explaining why he thought a buyer should have a chance at self-defense after board rejection, insisted: ''A person is left pondering, 'Why was I rejected; was it that they thought I couldn't afford it, or was it because they had some kind of prejudice?' ''

If applicants are being rejected for economic reasons, Mr. Levy said, they should ''have the opportunity to dispel misconceptions'' and show their earning power, whether it is child support not taken into account, or the future income of the self employed.

Recently, Mr. Kaplan and Ms. Engel of the Realtors' board met to discuss the law with Edward P. Mangano, the Nassau executive. He later expressed his support by describing its passage as ''a matter of putting pen to paper.''

Martha Krisel, Nassau's chief deputy county attorney for special projects, said that although county housing law applied to all housing, including co-ops, and although it prohibited discriminatory practices, ''co-op boards do have their own rules.''

Moreover, according to Ms. Engel, the law also ensures that boards no longer drag their feet in considering applications.

''The co-op boards must within 45 days give an acceptance or a rejection for the prospective owner,'' she said, ''and they had not done that in the past. They just put it off and put it off.''

In the 1980s, Ms. Engel recalled, she was ''a victim of discrimination when it came to mortgages,'' because she was a single mother. ''It was horrible,'' she said. ''I had to get a co-signer. Do you know how embarrassing that is? I was the bread earner.''

Under the new law, co-ops must use a standardized application. ''They can't arbitrarily make a more onerous application for someone they want to eliminate,'' Ms. Ford said.

In a survey four years ago, she added, local Realtors were polled about transactions in which ''they knew discrimination was involved.'' In more than 100 they described ''a situation where the buyers had been rejected and they felt strongly that it had been discrimination.''

Similarly, when she did co-op conversion work in the 1980s, Ms. Ford recalled, ''it was blatantly brought up that they didn't want to let that person in'' for reasons that included race, ethnicity and disability. ''All you had to do was reject them,'' she said. ''You didn't have to give a reason.''

She added, ''If a bank declines to give you a mortgage, they have to tell you why. But this segment of the real estate market has been able to avoid those kinds of responsibilities.''

V. Elaine Gross, the director of Erase Racism, a nonprofit advocacy group based in Syosset, said the new law was ''definitely a step in the right direction.''

Mr. Levy called the legislation ''a preventive measure'' and hoped it would be instituted statewide.

PHOTO: STARTING WITH SUFFOLK: Members of the Long Island Board of Realtors, which backed a new co-op law: Kathy Engel, the president, left; Barbara Ford; Marian Fraker-Gutin; and Randy L. Kaplan. (PHOTOGRAPH BY RUBY WASHINGTON/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company

Q &A
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
Good Luck Having
By JAY ROMANO
561 words
21 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
8
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

Good Luck Having

A Sleepover Party

QOur co-op board wants to impose a requirement for owners to get signed permission from management, 48 hours in advance, to have overnight guests. Is this legal?

A ''I am unaware of any city or state law dealing with this subject,'' said Steven Troup, a Manhattan co-op and condominium lawyer. ''But I strongly suspect that the proposed restrictive guest policy is unenforceable.'' Mr. Troup says that while boards have wide latitude regarding policies in a co-op, a court is likely to find the proposal an unreasonable infringement on privacy. Mr. Troup said the shareholders should petition the board, in writing, to abandon the plan.

Higher Maintenance

For Ground-Floor Unit

QI am a co-op owner at a 90-unit building in Midtown. My ground-floor two-bedroom unit has been allocated the most shares in the building, for no apparent reason. (When I bought the apartment, I was told that it could also be used commercially.) My neighbors on higher floors, with the same square footage, pay less maintenance. Can I sue the building to reallocate the shares?

A ''Share allocations in a co-op are set at the time the building is converted and are virtually impossible to overturn,'' said Aaron Shmulewitz, a Manhattan co-op and condo lawyer. Several factors are considered when share allocations are initially set, he said, including size and location in the building.

The basis for the larger share allocation in this case might have been because the space was potentially convertible to commercial use. ''It is very unlikely that a court would order the board to reduce the number of shares,'' Mr. Shmulewitz said.

When a Rented Unit

Goes on the Market

QWe rented a two-bedroom in a condominium building about eight months ago. The apartment needed substantial work to make it habitable, including cleaning, painting and having new windows installed, all at our expense. (We failed to make a thorough inspection before renting.) Now we've been informed the owners plan to sell. I fear that our final months here will be compromised by buyers looking at the place. What are our rights?

A According to Jonathan H. Newman, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, renters generally have an obligation to allow an owner to show an apartment to prospective buyers. (If there is a lease, it should provide some guidance.) Typically, the frequency of such visits must be reasonable, he said, and adequate notice must be given to the tenant.

What is ''reasonable'' or ''adequate,'' however, depends upon the circumstances. The tenant can work out a timetable with the owner, or decline to allow ''unreasonable'' visits with ''inadequate'' notice. If the tenant chooses the latter option, the owner can start an action in Housing Court and ask the court to decide whether the visits are reasonable and occur with enough notice.

As for the repairs, Mr. Newman said, renters are protected by New York's ''implied warranty of habitability,'' which requires owners to ensure that residential apartments are free of conditions that could pose a threat to life, safety or well-being. So, he said, the writer should consult a lawyer to determine whether a claim against the landlord can be made to recover any costs incurred. JAY ROMANO

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100321e63l0007j


LIVING IN SEA CLIFF, L.I.
Real Estate Desk; SECTRE
The Village of Artful Lodgings
By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER
1593 words
21 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
7
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

ON a drive around Nassau County two and a half years ago, Paul and Jill Haining of Jackson Heights, Queens, fell in love with Sea Cliff, a quirky, gingerbread-laced village overlooking Hempstead Harbor on the North Shore.

It is only a square mile in area, but they discovered that space had been put to excellent use. In addition to beaches, vistas and parks, they found Gothic and Victorian ''painted ladies,'' quaint Arts and Crafts cottages, and good schools.

All of this banished their thoughts of upsizing to a three-bedroom apartment in Queens, sending them instead on a search of the narrow streets and steep hillsides in this outpost of about 5,000, for a house to call their own.

Last month the Hainings paid $669,000 -- list price -- for a stone-and-stucco three-bedroom English Cotswold-style cottage, built in 1918 on a 90-by-100-foot lot. (About two-thirds of Sea Cliff's homes and commercial buildings predate World War II.)

''It was priced right and had multiple bids on it,'' said Mr. Haining, 41, a vice president of Skanska U.S.A. Building, a civil engineering firm. He and his wife are expecting a baby; the setup seemed ''ideal to start a family'' -- and also for the eventual purchase of a boat, which could be moored at the marina at Harry Tappen Beach, an Oyster Bay town facility.

The more time the Hainings have spent in town, frequenting the restaurants, the more charmed they have felt. ''Everybody seems friendly, down to earth -- no one has false pretenses,'' Mr. Haining said. ''There are a lot of community programs and events going on.''

On a recent snowy night, for instance, 150 residents joined a pub crawl fund-raiser for the local beach association, paying $25 each to wander from restaurant to bar along Sea Cliff Avenue, the main shopping and dining street.

Similarly, in June, 120 families will set out cast-off treasures in a community garage sale, their homes marked on a map drawn up by the civic association. Then, at a local park on the last day of school, the association hosts an ice cream social, scooping out 200 free sundaes. And come October, in a ritual that dates back 30 years, newcomers will be invited to a party at a resident's home to be introduced to the mayor, the trustees and the librarians.

''It's the personal touch,'' said Ann DiPietro, head of the Sea Cliff Civic Association. ''We try to make everyone feel part of the village immediately.''

Though increasingly upscale of late, Sea Cliff retains its aura as a bohemian outpost in the midst of cookie-cutter suburbia -- an artists' haven of sorts.

Rose Gunter, who sings on Wednesday nights at Roots, a SoHo-esque restaurant on Sea Cliff Avenue with menu offerings like bacon-wrapped meatloaf, says she still has the ''hippie mentality'' that propelled her to Sea Cliff from the more staid Garden City three decades ago. ''It was handyman specials and people with long hair,'' recalled Ms. Gunter, 60. ''It's beautifully insidious and you can't leave. Even if you do, it draws you back.''

Terry Sciubba, broker-owner of Sherlock Homes Realty and a 30-year resident, explained it this way: ''It's not like a typical Nassau County bedroom community. It's still funky. If they don't want the funk, they go to Glen Head.''

WHAT YOU'LL FIND

Sea Cliff, in the Town of Oyster Bay, hugs the shoreline south of Glen Cove and north of Glenwood Landing. It is bounded to the east by Glen Cove Avenue and the unincorporated areas of Glen Head.

Among its roughly 2,000 residences, the village has cottages, bungalows and smaller Victorians with granny porches packed together along narrow streets at its heart, and larger Gothic and Victorian homes built into hillsides with commanding water views.

''Because they value these properties, people have gone to great lengths to restore them,'' said Wayne P. McCann, broker-owner of Harmonious Homes. ''You won't find as much vinyl as in other communities.''

Fifty-four buildings have local landmark status, and 29 of those are also on state and national registries, including Village Hall and the English Tudor-style fire department.

Strict architectural-review and zoning requirements are viewed as a safeguard of the old-time ambience. ''We are pretty controlling,'' said Bruce Kennedy, the mayor. ''We are trying to enjoy the same quality of life we have been enjoying for 125 years.''

Recent improvements include a new boardwalk connecting the business district and the waterfront -- long overdue, in some residents' view, as the last one was destroyed in the hurricane of 1938. Also, new streetlights and a village square clock have been added on Sea Cliff Avenue. And public and private foundation money was recently allocated for a $175,000 covered outdoor arts pavilion at the beach for live performances, Mr. Kennedy said.

The postwar part of the village, on its eastern fringes, is home to a mix of Capes, colonials, split-levels and the occasional contemporary.

WHAT YOU'LL PAY

Prices have slipped, but ''not as steeply as the rest of Long Island,'' said Dan Maddock, the village administrator and assessor. ''There has always been an irrational appeal for the village and the Victorian houses because of its quaintness,'' he said.

Patricia Desocio, an agent with Charles Rutenberg Realty, said Sea Cliff ''seems to hold its value because it is very artsy,'' but she also cited its wealth of homes with harbor views and their appeal to buyers from Manhattan.

Mr. McCann enumerated a few other factors he viewed as assets: the one-hour commute to New York, a small-town atmosphere and walkability.

The Multiple Listing Service of Long Island recorded 38 sales in 2008, for an average of $713,000. Last year there were 30 sales, and the average dropped by 14.9 percent, to $607,000. But the average length of time on the market held steady for each year, at 104 days.

''Prices were lower because the lower end sold,'' Ms. Sciubba said, citing first-time buyers wooed by the federal tax credit. It was the million-dollar-plus market that stalled.

Thirty-nine homes are now for sale: a four-room cottage on a 20-by-60-foot lot is listed at $319,000; a six-bedroom 1893 Victorian on a 99-by-172-foot lot is priced at $2.5 million.

Two- to three-bedroom houses on tight lots can fetch as much as $550,000. Three- to four-bedroom Victorians, colonials and Capes on 60-by-90-foot lots range from $550,000 to $700,000.

Eileen B. Heimer, a broker at Daniel Gale in Glen Head, said that of the five house rentals, the cheapest was a one-bedroom cottage, for $1,300, the priciest a two-bedroom colonial, for $2,300.

WHAT TO DO

Memorial Park, also known as Hippie Park, has an unobstructed view of Hempstead Harbor. On summer Thursday nights, its concerts (lemonade and cookies provided) draw a crowd. On Friday evenings the music revs up at Sea Cliff Beach. Harry Tappen Beach has a swimming pool, a playground, small boat launches and a 272-slip marina. The Sea Cliff Museum, in a former parsonage adjacent to Village Hall, is open on Sunday afternoons. The five-acre Clifton Park has ball fields. Central and Prospect Parks have playgrounds.

THE SCHOOLS

Sea Cliff is part of the well-regarded North Shore School District, which has 2,876 students and also draws from neighboring Glen Head, Glenwood Landing and Old Brookville. There are three kindergarten-through-fifth-grade schools in total, but village children attend the Sea Cliff Elementary School, then North Shore Middle and High Schools, both in Glen Head.

SAT averages in 2009 were 553 in reading, 587 in math and 550 in writing, versus 485, 502 and 478 statewide.

THE COMMUTE

All but one morning and one evening rush-hour Long Island Rail Road train between Sea Cliff and Pennsylvania Stations transfer at either Jamaica or Mineola. The transfer ride takes about an hour, the express ride a few minutes less. A monthly pass is $204, discounted 5 percent if bought online.

Sea Cliff is 23 miles from Midtown Manhattan. The drive via the Long Island Expressway takes about 45 minutes, or an hour in heavy traffic.

THE HISTORY

In the mid-1800s, Sea Cliff was a campground for Methodist revival meetings. Its close-set tent sites eventually became lots for small bungalows. By the end of that century the place was a resort. City visitors arrived by steamship and stayed at village hotels or boarding houses, some of which ended up converted for use as private homes. It was wealthy families from Brooklyn who built the large Victorians on the hillsides for their summertime use. The village was incorporated in 1883.

A Methodist tabernacle built during Sea Cliff's early campground years was used in the next century as a summer theater; actors like Yul Brynner, Shirley Booth and Basil Rathbone performed. The theater burned down in the mid-1950s.

PHOTO: AGLOW: Sunset in Sea Cliff, whose bungalows and Victorians often come with water views. Many homes have been carefully restored; as one broker put it, ''You won't find as much vinyl as in other communities.'' (PHOTOGRAPH BY KATHY KMONICEK FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

MAPS

The New York Times Company

TOWN CRIER
Magazine Desk; SECTMM
The Optimist's Blogger
By MARK OPPENHEIMER
3037 words
21 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
52
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

In February 2001,a Brown University graduate with the improbably suave name Lockhart Steele took up occupancy in a one-bedroom third-floor walk-up apartment on Rivington Street, near the intersection with Ludlow. The Lower East Side could still claim, just barely, to be a marginal neighborhood. Storefront synagogues and housing projects were still more typical than bars with ostentatiously unmarked doors. The neighborhood was a good fit for Lockhart Steele: they were both, as they say, in transition.

At the time, Steele's most glorious accomplishment was five years in the past. As a college senior, he co-wrote and self-published a compendium about the band Phish that soon became a bible for the band's international tribe of followers. But by 2001, he had left a job with an electronics trade magazine and then presided over the failure of an Internet start-up. Steele was a native of Manchester-by-the-Sea, Mass., where, he says, ''they cared more about where you went to boarding school than where you went to college.'' But Steele (St. Paul's School, Class of 1992) was a city boy now, and when he came home to the Lower East Side he was intrigued by what he saw. New people were moving into the neighborhood -- younger people, interesting people. New restaurants and bars followed. Boutiques, too. Music clubs. Lots of life.

Over the next year, he began posting to his Web site photographs of the neighborhood, as well as short news items about local goings-on. Soon, Lockhartsteele.com was an eccentric guide to a certain New York, reflecting the author's interests and the era in which he wrote. In October 2003 he posted about, among other things, the disgraced author James Frey, Schiller's Liquor Bar and Friendster. And about real estate -- Lachlan Murdoch's purchase of 11 Spring Street, Moby's rumored move to Essex and Canal. By early 2004, the site was getting about 3,000 page-views a day, largely on the strength of his wide-ranging real estate posts, which covered apartments, condos, restaurant openings and closings -- anything a New Yorker might do with square footage, a lease and a dream.

In May 2004, Steele corralled his real estate posts onto a new site he called Curbed.com. The next year, Steele broke restaurants away to form Eater.com, a site he founded with Ben Leventhal, who now works for NBC; in 2007, shopping news moved to Racked.com. Since then, Curbed has also expanded to the Hamptons, Los Angeles and San Francisco; Racked is in Los Angeles as well as New York; Eater is in five cities, including Miami and Portland, Ore.; and a blog for travelers, Gridskipper, has joined the empire. But Steele's flagship remains New York Curbed, which, with its mix of original reporting, smart packaging of links and tips from readers, has become a prime purveyor of New York real estate porn: closing prices, zoning scuttlebutt, developers' delays, digital pictures taken at open houses.

Amazingly, the audience for Curbed NY has grown steadily, even through the real estate downturn. At first, Steele figured that because Curbed was the quintessential read for good times, its finances would suffer in a recession. He laid off three people in New York, several more nationwide (about 10 to 20 percent of payroll, Steele estimates). But for Curbed the hard times never came. The New York site had 2.6 million unique visitors in 2009, its most ever, about 400,000 more than in 2008; Steele says that advertising revenue went up even faster, by 30 percent last year (Curbed won't release dollar amounts), and that the business started making a profit in the second half of 2009. Steele, who is now 36, explains the counterintuitive growth two ways. First, the young business simply kept growing up, getting better at selling ads, for example. Second, real estate companies ''that were buying full-page ads in Vanity Fair'' began making smaller, focused buys, and that was very good for sites like Curbed.

Both explanations make sense, but the rosy numbers also seem to validate Steele's original insight: that people are creatures of the neighborhood. Curbed, Eater and Racked are all broken down by borough -- Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens only -- with each borough searchable by neighborhood: NoLIta, SoHo and NoHo/Central Village may all be traversable in one 10-minute perambulation, but in Steele's world, each is its own precinct, with its own heroic architects, villainous developers, quixotic preservationists and celebrity real estate agents.

Steele says that with the crash, Curbed's editorial tone became less cheeky and more sensitive to people's pain. That may be so, but the site still carries, in an obvious way, the DNA of the gossip site Gawker. Steele was the editorial director of Gawker Media, which also includes gossip sites like Deadspin, Gizmodo and Jezebel, from 2005 to 2007. The Gawker voice -- which Steele helped hone -- is snarky and knowing, but above all, it is episodic. In the Gawker world, every item is potentially part of a longer drama, a narrative to unfold in time (with links to old Gawker posts). At Curbed, the dramatis personae aren't adulterous actors and politicians but buildings, whose fortunes and misfortunes are chronicled in order to help the discerning buyer and to provide schadenfreude to the salivating reader.

To take one example, the Palazzo Grey, a tenement redeveloped for five condominium units on Grand Street, has been the subject of seven posts in the last 18 months. The first post, in September 2008, mocked the building's Italianate name and inflated price tag. Subsequent posts mocked the owners' inability to find any buyers and the eventual leasing of ground-floor space to a Subway sandwich shop. The last post, from July 23, is a classic of Curbed sass, mocking several other Manhattan properties to boot: ''The city's finest new luxury residential buildings have a long and proud history of rewarding buyers with quick and easy dining options as close as possible to the comfort of their new homes. On 23rd Street, Gramercy Starck brought in the Golden Arches, leading to the 'McStarck' nickname. . . . In Harlem's record-setting 111 Central Park North, the more health-conscious Subway took space. Continuing that trend, and confirming a tipster's report, BelDel beacon Palazzo Grey has unveiled its new tenant. Eat fresh, Palazzo Grey, but know that Palazzo Chupi would never sink to such depths.''

Curbed's open derision can certainly infuriate the city's developers and brokers. But none of them will say an unkind word about Steele. In part that's surely because he wields a certain amount of power: after what you just read, would you buy a unit in Palazzo Grey? But it's also because Curbed appeals to so many audiences: real-estate daydreamers; neighborhood residents who mourn the loss of local news in other venues; and industry professionals for whom Curbed is essential reading and, for top brokerages like Corcoran, Stribling and Prudential Douglas Elliman, an advertising venue. Above all, Curbed has become a buyer's tip sheet. Along with blogs like Brownstoner.com (based in Brooklyn), StreetEasy.com (heavier on the sales figures and lighter on the gossip) and BrickUnderground.com, Steele's site is a first stop for New Yorkers ready to move.

Curbed, like Gawker, can be moralizing, even censorious. Just ask architects like Robert M. Scarano Jr. and Karl Fischer, perennial Curbed villains. But that's surely one reason that so many in the real estate community respect Steele. They see in him someone who thinks deeply about the character of neighborhoods. They notice that Curbed reserves its harshest criticism for those who flout zoning laws or -- worse -- do uncreative work. They recognize, above all, that at a time when the real estate market is as soft as a two-minute egg, Lockhart Steele keeps the faith.

Steele's implicit optimism -- that real estate, even when it deserves to be mocked, is always worth the attention -- makes him infectious. The first person I asked about Steele was Rachel Sklar, the former Huffington Post media writer, known for not suffering fools and for uncovering a lot of them. I expected a cool appraisal, some choice words putting Steele in context and taking the measure of the man. Here, in slightly condensed version, is what she said:

''The first time I met him, I responded the way a lot of people respond, which is, 'You're Lockhart Steele!' And going on and on about how his name sounded like a James Bond character -- how intimidating is that! Lockhart Steele with babes on each arm! Lockhart Steele will engage in a death battle in a back alley and emerge with a martini. Lock has been everywhere. . . . I have been to the Hamptons with Lock. Only once, but that counts. It's the only way to go to the Hamptons. . . . It is de rigueur for Lock to show up at various Manhattan A-list parties. He is that guy now. But he doesn't stray far from his intellectual, classically geeky roots, no matter how fabulously collared his flowered shirts are. . . . He's not just a real estate nerd. He is a fully formed New York renaissance man for the Internet era.''

But Sklar insisted that while she had been to the Hamptons with Lock, and adored Lock, she wasn't in his inner circle. For that point of view, I had to talk to Brooke Hammerling, who founded Brew Media Relations, a hip public relations firm in New York. She was similarly effusive. ''He knows things are going to happen before they happen,'' she told me. ''He explained blogging to me before blogging was a known thing. Same with Twitter. Same with Foursquare. All mainstream now, naturally. He's my guide through the Internet world. My Yoda is Lockhart.''

When asked about Steele, Dottie Herman, the head of Prudential Douglas Elliman Real Estate, the grand white-shoe firm, was less starry-eyed but in her way no less complimentary. She's more famous, and certainly more feared, than Steele, so she didn't sound overawed by him. But she sees in him a fellow entrepreneur and a useful ally -- she often feeds him tips about her new listings. Herman once invited Steele to address her senior managers. The way Steele tells it, she interrupted him at one point to announce to her employees that they had better pay attention to what he was saying. The Internet was the future of real estate, and Lockhart Steele was the Internet. Herman confirms the story: ''I said, 'Listen, the way you do it is over, and you better get with it.' ''

What she meant is that thanks to people like Steele, the broker's job has changed. ''It's like if you get sick now, a lot of people will go to WebMD first,'' Herman says -- and Curbed is WebMD for real estate, the site where the novice goes to get up to speed. ''Your consumer is more informed, but not necessarily better informed.'' The broker's job is no longer to tell people what a house is worth, or what nearby properties have sold for -- everybody knows that now. Instead, a broker is more useful calming down a buyer agitated by a proliferation of Web gossip. The broker is less salesman, more therapist, or oracle. And by professional obligation, a daily reader of real estate blogs.

The most sober assessment I heard of Steele came from the man himself. We spoke several times on the phone, then finally met for dinner at Momofuku Ssam Bar, the East Village restaurant owned by David Chang, who is a friend of Steele's. I recognized Steele. We debated against each other in regional competitions in high school, 20 years ago. And here, sitting across the table from me, was the same guy, practically unchanged, with the shaggy bowl cut and the soft voice. I was hoping to see one of the famous flowered shirts that Rachel Sklar had mentioned, but tonight his sweater and button-down could have come from the back of his prep-school closet. He didn't seem cool, which is probably why his cool friends think he's so cool. He wouldn't talk about his romantic life, but in other ways he was earnest and forthcoming. He volunteered that his father drank himself to death three years ago. And he told me that in 1997, he killed a St. Paul's classmate, his best friend, John-Christophe Schlesinger.

''If you're going to do a story about me, you should know the story,'' Steele said. ''I was driving early in the morning, and I fell asleep at the wheel, and we crashed and he died. It's something that's with me every day.'' I asked about how Schlesinger's parents treated him after that. ''If at some point in my life,'' he said, ''I am as good to people as they have been to me, that would be amazing.''

After that, it was tough to ask Steele really pointed questions, but I tried. Curbed seems to waste little space on apartments worth less than half a million dollars, and Steele had already admitted, during one phone call, that Curbed didn't do much, or enough, to cover real estate in the normal person's price range. ''I think it's a fair critique,'' he said. ''I make this joke that blogs exist because people are bored at work -- which is to say people with white-collar jobs and big screens to stare at. That's undeniable.'' But he was not willing to admit that that might be a bad mission. To him, it was virtuous. ''If we're serving our audience, which is what any self-respecting publication should do, then undeniably we're serving a more upscale audience than any slice of New York.'' But it still might be morally ambiguous. ''Part of the job of Curbed is to turn news into something wry and readable. But how do you do that with affordable housing? We try to cover that, but when we do, we end up as dry and self-important as those topics can be.''

The fact that Curbed doesn't even cover the Bronx, for instance, suggests the limits of the Lockhart Steele vision, as well as the limits of what high-end advertisers want to support. At dinner, he tried, with some success, to have it both ways. ''I am not,'' he said, ''going to deny there is some general societal good in creating entertaining media. It's fun, and I don't think we need to pretend to a higher good than that to justify our existence.'' But, he added, ''if I were going to try to pretend we're doing some great societal good, we're part of this overall trend toward transparency. This industry has been traditionally closed to consumers. . . . We create more of a balance of power between the industry and the people making the biggest purchase of their lives.''

To create that balance of power, the information needs to be reliable, and Curbed has made strides in ensuring the accuracy of its reporting. ''If you look back at what blogging was five years ago,'' Steele said, ''the rules have transitioned from being a little bit Wild West, anything goes to drawing closer to fundamental rules in play for print publications.'' He pointed to a story Curbed ran on Jan. 21 about a building at 211 Elizabeth Street. ''It's really fancy, a condo building, prices high, has a name-brand interior designer, name-brand real estate brokerage is selling it. Every reason to believe it's a quality project. But we get an e-mail from a reader who has purchased in the building and is very, very unhappy with the quality of work in this place. And she sent us basically a rant -- water leak, flood.'' In the old days, Steele says, he might have just posted the rant.

But in this case, Steele said, his writer Joey Arak wrote to the woman. ''He writes back to her, like, 'O.K., if we're going to do this story, like, do you have some photos or other ways to back up your claims?' Sure enough, she sends on a whole bunch of photos. Then we go to the developers, like, 'Hey we got this complaint from a reader, do you want to respond?' And the final post includes the woman's claims, photos and a post from the developer. That is pretty standard journalism.''

Well, more or less -- Arak didn't ask to see the condo in question or track down other owners in the building. But in the Curbediverse, as the site modestly calls the world whose story it tells, every new building, every architectural misstep, every bit of shoddy construction, every scrumptious Sunday open house and every regrettable ground-floor Subway has its moment on the screen, for all eyes to see. So that neighbors can whisper, so that buyers can reconsider the neighborhood.

Steele still lives in the same Rivington Street apartment whose sidewalk life inspired him to start blogging. ''I am probably about ready to buy a place and have been too busy working to get around to it,'' he said. He's ''probably overdue for a move.'' It's ''probably ridiculous'' that he has stayed in one place. Then again, it seems doubtful that he's in a hurry to leave. ''I like where I live,'' he said, as if a confession has been forced from him. ''I love my neighborhood.''

And if he were to move, if he were to raise the profile of some new building with his very chic, very flower-shirted presence, then tell me: who would tip off Curbed?

PHOTO (PHOTOGRAPH BY RYAN PFLUGER) (MM53)

Mark Oppenheimer writes the Beliefs column for The Times. He is also an editor for The New Haven Review, and his memoir, ''Wisenheimer: A Childhood Subject to Debate,'' will be published in April.

The New York Times Company

Business/Financial Desk; SECTB
Up North, Real Estate Is Booming. Seriously.
By IAN AUSTEN
941 words
20 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
3
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

OTTAWA -- Marie-Yvonne Paint, a real estate agent in Montreal, has the kind of problem most of her counterparts in the United States can only dream about.

''We have a shortage of inventory right now,'' said Ms. Paint, who focuses on the exclusive and expensive municipality of Westmount. ''It's very annoying. We have buyers ready to buy and not much to show.''

Ms. Paint's experience is not an isolated example. Like most of the world, Canada's real estate market slumped during the recession. But now, instead of worrying about the recovery of the real estate market, some Canadians are concerned about the prospect of a price bubble. The Canadian Real Estate Association reported that the average price of existing homes rose 19.6 percent in January compared with those in the month a year earlier, the latest in a string of substantial gains dating back through last autumn. By contrast, the average price of existing homes rose 2.6 percent in the United States in the same period, according to the National Association of Realtors.

Such drastic percentage gains are not just a reflection of the market's earlier depths. In some Canadian cities, particularly Toronto and Vancouver, prices appear to be heading toward record levels.

''It's no surprise the housing market responded to low interest rates,'' said Craig Alexander, the deputy chief economist of the Toronto-Dominion Bank. ''The real question is what's going to happen in the next year. It can't continue at the current pace, otherwise a bubble will form.''

Canadian home buyers, of course, are not unique in having access to low-interest mortgages. But Mr. Alexander and others attribute the Canadian market's revival to a series of measures that ensured that the recession in Canada did not turn into a real estate disaster.

Perhaps chief among them is the country's retail banking system, which is effectively an oligopoly dominated by five national banks, including Toronto-Dominion.

Most of the time, that arrangement is less than popular among Canadians, who think that a lack of competition leads to, among other things, low interest rates on savings and high service fees.

Public resentment has repeatedly caused politicians to block mergers between the banks. But in the lead-up to the credit crisis, the closed-shop nature of banking in Canada proved to be the government's, and the economy's, best friend.

Mindful of government oversight, Canadian banks by and large avoided the structured debt products that imperiled many of their American counterparts. They also maintained comparatively tight controls on mortgage lending to consumers. When zero percent down payments on mortgages were widely available in the United States, Canadians were typically required to put down at least 10 percent. American-style amortization periods stretching beyond 25 years were also relatively unknown in Canada.

''In Canada, standards got nowhere near as low,'' said Timothy D. Hockey, the chief executive of TD Canada Trust, Toronto-Dominion's Canadian retail banking operation. ''When the crisis came upon us, the standards didn't have to change.''

One result of that, said Phil Soper, the president and chief executive of Brookfield Real Estate Services of Toronto, is that the slump in housing starts and existing home prices was delayed by about a year in Canada until late 2008. Then, when interest among buyers began to return last year, Canada's still-healthy banks were able to provide mortgages, and housing prices were not depressed by a glut of defaulted properties in forced sales.

''One of the things we see in American businesses that we don't see in our Canadian businesses is a willingness to really push the limits,'' said Mr. Soper, whose operations include Royal LePage, one of Canada's leading real estate brokers. ''When bubbles burst, sometimes the turtle wins.''

While demand from buyers has returned, most real estate analysts agree that sellers have been slower to move. There are a variety of theories for that reluctance. Winter is not seen as a optimal season for selling homes in most parts of the country, given Canada's climate. Some economists speculate that many sellers are holding out for more definitive signs of a market comeback. And others think that many sellers have delayed putting their homes on the market because they are undertaking repairs prompted by recently expired home renovation tax credits that were part of Canada's economic recovery plan.

But whatever the cause, the expectation -- or perhaps the hope -- is that the arrival of spring and the upward trend in prices will inspire increasing numbers of people to list their homes. The increase in supply, in turn, should prevent prices from escalating to bubble levels. January's statistics, both for resales and housing starts, suggest that pattern may be developing.

But Mr. Soper is among those who caution against reading too much into the current market buoyancy about long-term price trends.

''Canadians in the financial and real estate sectors feel a little bit smarter than they should about the strength of the economy and industry over the last few years,'' he said. ''Certainly the underlying economy isn't strong enough to support the prices we've seen over the last few weeks.''

PHOTOS: A property for sale in the Outremont section of Montreal. Its owners are asking $6.3 million amid rising real estate prices.; Marie-Yvonne Paint, a real estate agent, in the Outremont home. Existing-home prices soared 19.6 percent in January in Canada. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY CHRISTINNE MUSCHI FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100320e63k0003d


THE TV WATCH
The Arts/Cultural Desk; SECTC
On HGTV, Fixing Homes And Hearts
By ALESSANDRA STANLEY
988 words
18 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
1
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

''The Grants are getting a divorce,'' Ian Kleier says after studying the gossip pages at the kitchen table of his Park Avenue apartment. His wife, Michele, is not surprised. ''I had my suspicions,'' she says, and starts to list the warning signs while scrambling eggs for ''the girls,'' the couple's trio of white Maltese. Ian cuts her off. ''It's not a pretty divorce, and I think you should jump right on top of it.''

It's like a scene from ''The Real Housewives of New York,'' only the Kleiers are the Real Realtors of New York, owners of a family-run real estate firm and, beginning on Thursday, stars of a new reality series on HGTV, ''Selling New York,'' which focuses on just that. The Kleiers, who are grandparents, sell multimillion-dollar apartments to an older Upper East Side clientele. They and their two daughters are matched up against younger, hipper brokers from another firm, Core, catering to young professionals willing to pay more than $2 million for downtown views, double sinks and rooftop pool parties that are, as one events planner puts it, ''a little Puff Daddyish.''

''Selling New York'' is a bit of a jolt because, at first glance, it looks like a flashback to pre-recession values. But it's less a harbinger of economic recovery than a midcourse correction for HGTV, a cable network that fed -- and feasted on -- the fantasies and delusions of the housing bubble and then, when that collapsed, went into austerity and atonement mode with series like the 2009 ''Real Estate Intervention.''

HGTV is getting its building buzz back, but gingerly. Most of the new series, and there are six of them in prime time alone, focus on modest middle-class home sales and improvement projects.

And like ''Selling New York,'' these new series have learned a lesson not from housing starts but from the ''Real Housewives'' franchise on Bravo: There is no dip in the market of people making spectacles of themselves.

Reality shows like ''Real Housewives'' -- be they of Orange County, Atlanta, New York or New Jersey -- ''The Bachelor,'' ''Jersey Shore'' (and a hair salon knockoff, ''Jerseylicious,'' on Style beginning this weekend) keep growing more stagily preposterous and rococo. Paradoxically, a few of them are tiptoeing around the housing market collapse too: Lynne, one of the housewives in Season 5 of ''Orange County,'' was forced to downsize, then was served an eviction notice on her Laguna Beach rental.

HGTV, however, is seeking shelter in Manhattan penthouses, beauty makeovers and home improvement for the heart.

When it began, ''Real Estate Intervention'' taught distraught homeowners how to deal with the collapse of the housing market. Now ''Home Rules,'' which had its premiere on Monday, teaches distraught homeowners how to deal with the collapse of their marriages -- while renovating their houses.

In the first episode the host, Fran Harris, a former WNBA player who is now a life coach, helps an estranged couple, Matt and Heather, rekindle their ardor; a new master bedroom and a remodeled kitchen are dangled as rewards for completing communication assignments, like listening. ''You work on your inner house,'' Ms. Harris says, ''we'll work on your outer house.''

While workers tear out pink countertops and replace rotting planks, Matt and Heather renew their vows on a gauzy, candlelit set that rivals the most poignant rose ceremony on ''The Bachelor.''

HGTV calls ''Tough as Nails,'' which begins on Thursday, a docudrama, but it looks more like a docu-telenovela, a weekly series about a tough, comely Boston developer, Cindy Stumpo, who barks orders at all-male construction crews but cannot still the yearnings of her own heart. Like Bathsheba Everdene, the Thomas Hardy heroine who is torn between a loyal farmhand and her rakish runaway husband, Cindy mistily tells the camera that she trusts and relies on Michael, her foreman, but still has ''feelings'' for her ex-husband, Joe.

''Marriage Under Construction,'' which began on Tuesday, follows a pair of newlyweds in Toronto, Natalie and Rod. Their marriage and tangential real estate problems are served up as a kind of romantic sitcom, an HGTV version of ''Tori &Dean: Home Sweet Hollywood.'' Rod, who has a burly ''King of Queens'' physique, is good-humored and somewhat slothful; Natalie is attractive, determined and a little bossy. While brushing her teeth, Natalie asks Rod, seated in front of a laptop, what he is doing. ''Looking at houses,'' he replies though he is playing backgammon on an online gaming site.

''My First Sale,'' starting Thursday, focuses on a different family each week but milks each housing decision for melodrama and whatever naughtiness it can glean. Shelly and Brian have a new baby and no privacy in the loftlike, one-bedroom that they're selling. They have to lower their price and just barely wrangle the mortgage for a bigger house.

They are last seen in their new kitchen, doors closed and blender whirring. ''So, is it bad that we sold our house and bought a new one so we could drink after the baby goes to bed?'' Brian asks.

''No,'' Shelly coos. ''No. I've been waiting to have margaritas for months.''

Even ''The Antonio Treatment,'' a design show that began on Sunday and stars Antonio Ballatore, the heavily tattooed winner of Season 4 of ''HGTV Design Star,'' tries to give some reality show hype along with moldings and ceiling frescos by focusing on his wacky construction crew, which includes heavy-metal musicians and an English bulldog named Chewy. Mr. Ballatore puts it this way, ''We all got these crazy personalities going on.''

And on HGTV it's the personalities that have room for improvement.

PHOTO: Cindy Stumpo (shown with Dave Baum), a Boston developer, is at the center of HGTV's new series ''Tough as Nails.'' (PHOTOGRAPH BY HGTV) (C7)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100318e63i0003d


SQUARE FEET
Business/Financial Desk; SECTB
Phoenix Meets the Wrong End of the Boom Cycle
By JOHN COLLINS RUDOLF
1294 words
17 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
6
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

PHOENIX -- Perhaps it was just a matter of time, but three years after this city's housing market collapsed in spectacular fashion, commercial real estate has followed it off the cliff.

The average price paid for office space in the Phoenix metro area tumbled more than 50 percent last year, from $205 a square foot in 2008 to $102 a square foot in 2009, according to data compiled by Kammrath &Associates, a local real estate analysis firm. Retail and industrial space underwent similar declines.

''Prices are falling like a stone,'' said Bob Kammrath, who has studied the commercial market in Phoenix since 1981. ''I see them going lower.''

The recession has been the main instigator of the crash, but overbuilding and speculation set the stage. In a mirror image of the housing bubble, relaxed lending standards and a boom mentality prompted the construction of hundreds of offices, shopping centers, industrial buildings, hotels and apartments from 2005 to 2009 -- about 86.5 million square feet of new commercial space in all, according to research by CB Richard Ellis.

In 2006, when growth peaked, about 30 percent of the Phoenix area's economic output was tied to real estate and construction. So it was not long after the once white-hot housing market fell apart, in 2007, that the rest of the city's economy stumbled, and hard. As jobs in construction and real estate dried up, and stock market losses curbed the relocation of retirees from the north, in-migration to the city radically slowed.

Commercial brokers blame a confluence of factors for the worst downturn in memory: rampant overbuilding, a national economic crisis, spiking unemployment and a near halt in population growth. The result is visible all over the city in the form of empty storefronts and ''for lease'' signs affixed to office buildings.

The worst-off of these projects were built in marginal locations on the outskirts of the metropolitan area, and stand completely empty months and even years after completion.

''We've got some see-through shopping centers,'' said David Wetta, senior vice president and managing director in the Phoenix office of the real estate brokerage Marcus &Millichap.

A handful of major developments throughout the metro area simply collapsed midconstruction and linger, half-built, as gloomy reminders of the sudden end of good times.

One such failure, the Hotel Monroe, sits in the heart of downtown Phoenix, just a few blocks from City Hall. Started in 2006, its plans were extravagant even by the bloated standards of the bubble era. The 144-room boutique hotel was to be housed in a rehabilitated 12-story Art Deco office building from the 1930s and would include opulent ''Rock Star'' suites, a five-star restaurant, a rooftop nightclub and 24-hour room service.

Construction began in 2007 but ground to a halt a year later when the project's banker, Mortgages Ltd. -- for a short time, Arizona's largest private lender -- cut off financing, en route to its own bankruptcy. The hotel remains unfinished, with dark windows and a desolate mien; Grace Communities, its developer, was recently cited by the City of Phoenix for code violations including graffiti on exterior walls and trash and debris around the premises.

When or how the hotel will be finished is uncertain, as the building is in foreclosure and headed to a trustee's sale in April. There, 13 investors will try to recoup $76.5 million in loans, though experts say the building is unlikely to fetch anywhere near that amount.

Yet it is not just new commercial developments that are foundering. Older properties -- in particular, those that sold at big premiums during the market run-up -- are also struggling with rising vacancy rates, shrinking rent rolls and high debt loads.

A prime example is the Viad Corporate Center, a 24-story, 478,000-square-foot high-rise in midtown Phoenix, which was built in 1991 and bought for an estimated $105 million in 2006. Earlier this month, Bank of America filed a motion in court to appoint a receiver for the property, citing the failure of the building's owner to stay current on a $65 million loan.

Bank of America's move to foreclose on the tower is one prominent sign that lenders are losing patience with large commercial borrowers and are stepping up efforts to resolve problem loans behind big properties. Commercial mortgages in Phoenix are souring at their highest rate in years: according to Foresight Analytics, a banking analysis firm, 5.3 percent of commercial mortgages in the metro area were delinquent in the fourth quarter of 2009, up from 2.3 percent at the same period in 2008.

Yet even as delinquencies climb, some analysts say lenders have not been aggressive enough in writing down loans and repossessing and disposing of properties -- often a painful process for both banks and borrowers.

''There's more to go, just to get caught up with the current volume of defaulted loans,'' said Matt Anderson, an analyst with Foresight Analytics.

High unemployment (over 9 percent here in February), combined with continued weakness in housing and sluggish consumer spending, will most likely prolong the pain in Phoenix's commercial market. Since the recession began nearly two years ago, many business owners here have dipped into savings and lines of credit in an effort to stay afloat. As these resources run out, more tenants are closing up shop.

Already, vacancies are at troubling levels: according to CB Richard Ellis, 25.4 percent of office space in the Phoenix metro area is unoccupied. Retail has also deteriorated: vacancy rates for that sector have risen the last 11 quarters, to 11.4 percent at the end of 2009. These rates may not reflect the full extent of the industry's weakness, however, as some landlords appear disinclined to evict even seriously delinquent tenants because of the difficulty of attracting businesses to replace them.

Yet despite the avalanche of negative indicators, some in the public and private sector are keen to point out bright spots for commercial real estate in the Phoenix area. Desirable pockets in affluent cities like Scottsdale have little vacant space available at any price, while areas close to the downtown core and along established urban corridors are weathering the storm fairly well. CityScape, a $900 million commercial development in the heart of downtown Phoenix that includes shops, restaurants and a 27-story office tower, is at least 75 percent leased months ahead of its scheduled opening this summer.

Billions of dollars in public investment in a light-rail system, and improvements to the Arizona State University campus and the Phoenix Convention Center, should also help commerce. The improvements are already helping downtown Phoenix shake its reputation as a ghost town after dark.

There is, too, no shortage of bargain properties to be leased or bought, particularly on the city's outskirts. Some assets are from portfolios of failed banks now held by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and are selling for rock-bottom prices.

The mood of commercial real estate professionals is improving, said Kevin Calihan, senior vice president at CB Richard Ellis in Phoenix. ''People are starting to feel the end is in sight,'' he said.

But others are less optimistic. ''We're in the first or second inning,'' said Mr. Wetta of Marcus &Millichap. ''We haven't seen the worst of it yet.''

PHOTOS: An old building in downtown Phoenix that was to be renovated into a boutique hotel is nearing foreclosure.; A hotel and condos were planned on 10.6 acres in Chandler, Ariz. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY JOSHUA LOTT FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

The New York Times Company

Document NYTF000020100317e63h0002j


Business/Financial Desk; SECTB
Housing Starts Are Slowed By Blizzards, as Expected
By JAVIER C. HERNANDEZ
677 words
17 March 2010
The New York Times
NYTF
Late Edition - Final
9
English
Copyright 2010 The New York Times Company. All Rights Reserved.

Home building slowed in February as snowstorms stopped construction in some of the country's largest markets, a Commerce Department report indicated Tuesday.

But the data suggested that builders might also be curtailing construction in response to disappointing demand, despite the government's efforts to lure buyers with a tax credit of up to $8,000.

Construction fell 5.9 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 575,000 homes, with much of the weakness in the Northeast and South, where the severe weather was concentrated. Building of single-family homes fell 0.6 percent.

''The outlook remains bleak,'' Paul Dales, an economist for Capital Economics, wrote in a research note. ''Home building activity remains very low by historical standards and is set to remain that way for some time.''

The drop in February followed an increase in January that was much better than initially reported. The government said Tuesday that construction increased 6.6 percent in January, nearly triple the original estimate, with much of the momentum coming from single-family homes.

Analysts had expected home construction to decrease by less in February, but those forecasts did not account for the surge in building in January.

The slowdown revived a debate about the potency of the tax credit for home buyers. While economists said most of the decline in February could be tied to weather, builders might also be responding to tepid demand.

Sales of new homes fell to a record low in January, resurrecting worries that consumers would delay home buying until the jobs market turned around. The government's tax credit helped lift sales in the fall. But analysts have yet to see the second wave of buying they predicted as the April 30 deadline for the credit approaches.

Indeed, building permits, which indicate future activity and were not affected by weather, fell 1.6 percent in February after robust gains in recent months.

A large supply of excess homes on the market is keeping builders on the sidelines. Economists estimate there are 3.8 million homes for sale in the United States, and the market may be flooded with an additional five million to six million in foreclosed properties over the next several years.

''It's still a real struggle for builders,'' said Nigel Gault, an economist for IHS Global Insight. ''They're competing with a lot of distressed properties on the market at bargain prices.''

The influx of foreclosed homes is also making it harder for Americans to sell their homes, contributing to the weak demand for new homes. Over the last year, the housing market has moved mostly sideways: the rate of construction was 0.2 percent higher in February compared with a year earlier.

Adding to the troubles is the foundering commercial real estate market, where vacancy rates are high and financiers are scarce. That has curbed apartment construction. In February, construction of apartments with five units or more fell 43.1 percent to an annual rate of 58,000 units, though economists cautioned that the trends could be exaggerated at such low levels.

The housing market's recovery may depend largely on how quickly unemployment eases. It may take several years before the jobless rate, now 9.7 percent, retreats to normal levels.

In part because of the weak jobs market, the Federal Reserve said on Tuesday that it would keep interest rates near zero for an extended period.

Despite the low rates, economists say inflation appears to be in check in the United States. A Labor Department report released Tuesday reinforced that view, with import prices, a gauge of inflation, falling 0.3 percent in February, mostly because of a decline in fuel prices.

PHOTO: Town houses being built in Des Plaines, Ill. Home construction fell 5.9 percent in February. (PHOTOGRAPH BY TIM BOYLE/BLOOMBERG NEWS)

CHART: Housing Construction: New private housing starts and permits authorized during the month, at a seasonally adjusted annual pace. (Source: Commerce Department)

The New York Times Company

HOUSING STARTS ARE SLOWED BY BLIZZARDS, AS EXPECTED
By JAVIER C HERNANDEZ
38 words
17 March 2010

Commerce Department reports February housing starts fell 5.9 percent from January, to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 575,000 homes; photo, graph (M)
